'''Third-party punishment''', or '''altruistic punishment''', is [[punishment]] of a transgressor (first party) which is administered, not by a victim of the transgression (second party), but rather by a third party not directly affected by the transgression.<ref name="Fehr">{{cite journal|last1=Fehr|first1=Ernst|author2=Fischbacher, Urs |year=2004|title=Third-party punishment and social norms |journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|volume=25|issue=2 |pages=63–87 |doi=10.1016/S1090-5138(04)00005-4 |url=http://econwpa.repec.org/eps/exp/papers/0409/0409002.pdf|citeseerx=10.1.1.120.5059}}</ref> It has been argued that third-party punishments are the essence of [[norm (social)|social norms]], as they are [[Evolutionarily stable strategy|evolutionary stable]] unlike second-party punishments.<ref name=Bendor>{{cite journal|last=Bendor|first=Jonathon|author2=Swistak, Piot |title=The Evolution of Norms|journal=American Journal of Sociology|year=2001|volume=106|issue=6|pages=1493–1545|doi=10.1086/321298}}</ref> It has also been shown that third-party punishments are exhibited in all examined populations, though the magnitude of the punishments varies greatly, and that costly punishment co-varies with [[Altruism|altruistic behavior]].<ref name=Henrich1>{{cite journal|last=Henrich|first=Joseph |author2=Richard McElreath |author3=Abigail Barr |author4=Jean Ensminger |author5=Clark Barrett |author6=Alexander Bolyanatz |author7=Juan Camilo Cardenas |author8=Michael Gurven |author9=Edwins Gwako |author10=Natalie Henrich |author11=Carolyn Lesorogol |author12=Frank Marlowe |author13=David Tracer |author14=John Ziker |title=Costly Punishment across Human Societies|journal=Science|year=2006|volume=312|series=New Series|issue=5781|pages=1767–1770|doi=10.1126/science.1127333|pmid=16794075|bibcode=2006Sci...312.1767H |citeseerx=10.1.1.714.70 }}</ref><ref name=Marlowe1>{{cite journal|last=Marlowe|first=Frank W.|author2=Berbesque, J. Colette |title=More 'altruistic' punishment in larger societies|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|year=2007|volume=275|issue=1634|pages=587–590|doi=10.1098/rspb.2007.1517|pmid=18089534|pmc=2596817}}</ref><ref name=Hadza>{{cite journal|last=Marlowe|first=Frank W.|title=Hadza Cooperation|journal=Human Nature|year=2009|volume=20|issue=4|pages=417–430|doi=10.1007/s12110-009-9072-6}}</ref> Differences between within-group and inter-group altruistic punishments have also been observed.<ref name=Parochial>{{cite journal|last=Bernhard|first=Helen|author2=Urs Fischbacher |author3=Ernst Fehr |title=Parochial altruism in humans|journal=Nature|year=2006|volume=442|issue=7105|pages=912–915|doi=10.1038/nature04981|pmid=16929297|bibcode=2006Natur.442..912B}}</ref>
==Experimental evidence== Some of the common experiments in [[experimental economics]] concerning the study of second-party punishments with respect to distribution and cooperation norms have been [[dictator game]]s and [[Prisoner's dilemma|prisoner's dilemma games]].<ref name="Fehr" /><ref name=Fehr2>{{cite journal|last=Fehr|first=Ernst|author2=Fischbacher, Urs |title=The nature of human altruism|journal=Nature|year=2003|volume=425|issue=6960|pages=785–91|doi=10.1038/nature02043|url=http://ebour.com.ar/pdfs/The%20nature%20of%20human%20altruism.pdf|pmid=14574401|bibcode=2003Natur.425..785F}}</ref> These games can also be effectively used in the study of third-party punishments with respect to distribution and cooperation norms with some modifications.
===Third-party dictator game=== Concerning third-party dictator game (TP-DG), the game was modified to include a third person with a punishment option between the dictator and the recipient. The dictator was given an endowment of 100, of which he could choose to share any portion with the recipient. The third person observer was also given an endowment of 50, of which he could choose to spend in order to punish the dictator. If self-interest was the driving force for the decision making, then the dictator would choose to donate none of his endowment, and the third party observer would choose to spend none of his endowment punishing the dictator. However, roughly 60% of the third party observers chose to punish dictators who donated less than half their endowment.<ref name="Fehr" />
In a variation of the TP-DG, the third party observer could choose to spend part of the endowment to punish the dictator or could spend part of the endowment to compensate the recipient. About 40% of the third party observers chose to do both, while 32% chose to compensate the recipient and only about 6% opted to punish only. This indicates that compensation is preferred over punishment in the TP-DG when an offer is perceived as unfair. This suggests that third-party punishment may be motivated by a desire to both provide justice for those who have been wronged and to reprimand those who violate expected social norms.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Punitive versus compensatory reactions to injustice: Emotional antecedents to third-party interventions|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022103110002210|journal = Journal of Experimental Social Psychology|date = 2011-03-01|pages = 477–480|volume = 47|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/j.jesp.2010.10.004|first = Sebastian|last = Lotz|first2 = Tyler G.|last2 = Okimoto|first3 = Thomas|last3 = Schlösser|first4 = Detlef|last4 = Fetchenhauer}}</ref>
===Third-party prisoner's dilemma=== Concerning third-party prisoner's dilemma (TP-PD), the game was modified so that in addition to two players who would choose to either cooperate or defect, a third party observer could choose to punish the players. The payoffs of the game were such that the players would be best off if they defected; however, if both players chose to defect, their payoff would be less than if they had cooperated. The observer could then choose to spend from his endowment to punish the defectors who chose to put self-interest ahead of cooperation. From previous theories,<ref name=Fischbacher1>{{cite journal|last=Fischbacher|first=Urs|title=Are people conditionally cooperative? Evidence from a public goods experiment|journal=Economics Letters|year=2001|volume=71|issue=3|pages=397–404|doi=10.1016/S0165-1765(01)00394-9|hdl=20.500.11850/146559}}</ref><ref name=Dawes1>{{cite journal|last=Dawes|first=Robyn M.|title=Social Dilemmas|journal=International Journal of Psychology|year=2000|volume=35|issue=2|pages=111–116|doi=10.1080/002075900399402}}</ref> it can be concluded that subjects are willing to cooperate if the probability that others will also do so is sufficiently large. Once again, if self-interest was the decision maker for these players, neither would choose to cooperate, and the observer would also choose to keep his full endowment and not issue any punishments. However, about 45.8% of observers chose to punish the defector when he is paired with a cooperator, and 20.8% chose to punish both players if they had both defected. It's important to note that the magnitude of punishment was much larger when one defected.<ref name="Fehr" />
===Second-party vs. third-party punishments=== With respect to the distribution norms violations (dictator games), it has been shown that second-party punishments are consistently higher than third-party punishments for dictators that choose to share less than half of their endowment. The punishments were such that the dictators could still profit from giving less than half in the third-party conditions, but could not profit in the second-party conditions. The levels of punishment were consistently low for both second and third-party punishments if the levels of endowment were higher than half.<ref name="Fehr" />
With respect to the cooperation norms violations (prisoner's dilemma), it has been shown that second-party punishments are consistently higher than third-party punishments for defectors. The punishments were such that the defectors could still profit in the third-party conditions, but could not profit in the second-party conditions. Punishment for cooperators were negligible under both conditions.<ref name="Fehr" />
==Evolution and neural basis== Current [[Sociocultural evolution|evolutionary models]] state that human altruism evolved through the selective (cultural or biological) extinction of groups in inter-group conflicts.<ref name=Gintis1>{{cite journal|last=Gintis, Herbert|title=Strong Reciprocity and Human Sociality|journal=Journal of Theoretical Biology|year=2000|volume=206|issue=2|pages=169–79|doi=10.1006/jtbi.2000.2111|pmid=10966755|citeseerx=10.1.1.335.7226}}</ref><ref name=Henrich2>{{cite journal|author1=Henrich, Joseph |author2=Boyd, Robert |title=Why People Punish Defectors Weak Conformist Transmission can Stabilize Costly Enforcement of Norms in Cooperative Dilemmas|journal=Journal of Theoretical Biology|year=2001|volume=208|issue=1|pages=79–89|doi=10.1006/jtbi.2000.2202|pmid=11162054}}</ref><ref name=Boyd1>{{cite journal|author1=Boyd, Robert |author2=Herbert Gintis |author3=Samuel Bowles |author4=Peter J. Richerson |title=The evolution of altruistic punishment|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|year=2003|volume=100|issue=6|pages=3531–3535|doi=10.1073/pnas.0630443100|pmid=12631700 |pmc=152327|bibcode=2003PNAS..100.3531B }}</ref> However, there is also evidence for altruism and norms between groups.<ref name="Parochial" /> Some models suggest that third party punishment of "free-riders" (those who do not cooperate) leads to increased group cooperation due to individual selection for cooperative traits.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Group Cooperation without Group Selection: Modest Punishment Can Recruit Much Cooperation|journal = PLoS ONE|date = 2015-04-20|pmc = 4404356|pmid = 25893241|pages = e0124561|volume = 10|issue = 4|doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0124561|first = Max M.|last = Krasnow|first2 = Andrew W.|last2 = Delton|first3 = Leda|last3 = Cosmides|first4 = John|last4 = Tooby}}</ref>
When subjects were examined with a [[Positron emission tomography|PET scan]] while playing a second-party [[Dictator Game|trust game]] with another player, it was shown that when they administered punishment, the [[dorsal striatum]], an area of the brain associated with the processing of rewards as a result of goal-directed actions, was activated. It was also shown that individuals with stronger activations of the dorsal striatum were willing to incur greater cost in order to punish the norm violator. This suggests that the people that administrated punishment against norm violators derived satisfaction from the act.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dominique J. -F. de Quervain, Urs Fischbacher, Valerie Treyer, Melanie Schellhammer, Ulrich Schnyder, Alfred Buck and Ernst Fehr|title=The Neural Basis of Altruistic Punishment|journal=Science|year=2004|volume=305|issue=5688|pages=1254–1258|doi=10.1126/science.1100735|pmid=15333831|bibcode=2004Sci...305.1254D}}</ref>
[[Functional magnetic resonance imaging|FMRI]] has also been used to examine third-party punishment. Subjects participated in a TP-DG during the scan as either a second party recipient or a third party observer. The [[nucleus accumbens]], a brain region associated with reward, had punishment-related activation for both the second-party and third-party punishment conditions. The overall pattern of activation was consistent between the two conditions, though activation was stronger in the second party recipients. This suggests that second-party and third-party punishment decisions have a common neural basis.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Beyond revenge: Neural and genetic bases of altruistic punishment|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1053811910010244|journal = NeuroImage|date = 2011-01-01|pages = 671–680|volume = 54|issue = 1|doi = 10.1016/j.neuroimage.2010.07.051|first = Alexander|last = Strobel|first2 = Jan|last2 = Zimmermann|first3 = Anja|last3 = Schmitz|first4 = Martin|last4 = Reuter|first5 = Stefanie|last5 = Lis|first6 = Sabine|last6 = Windmann|first7 = Peter|last7 = Kirsch|pmid=20673803}}</ref>
==Cross-culture variations== It has been shown that altruistic punishment exists across many examined populations, but that there is also a large variance between them. Data gathered from 15 different populations showed that when participating in TP-DG, all societies showed a decreasing frequency of punishment as the dictator's offer approached 50%. There was, however, a large variance between societies as to how much of their endowment the observers were willing to pay in order to punish the dictator. These variances were not attributed to economic and demographic variables. It was also found that societies with high degrees of punishment also exhibit more altruistic behavior.<ref name="Henrich1" /> Other studies have suggested that people in larger, more complex societies engage in significantly more third-party punishment than people in small-scale societies.<ref name="Marlowe1" />
== Gender and age differences == Women have been found to contribute more in dictator games and also to be more likely to accept an offer than men, rather than to reject an offer to punish the dictator. This was found for second-party punishment experiments but has not been observed in studies examining third-party punishment.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Chivalry and solidarity in ultimatum games|journal = Economic Inquiry|date = 2001-04-01|issn = 1465-7295|pages = 171–188|volume = 39|issue = 2|doi = 10.1111/j.1465-7295.2001.tb00059.x|first = Cc|last = Eckel|first2 = Pj|last2 = Grossman}}</ref> In mock trial experiments studying third-party punishment using legal scenarios, woman majority mock juries are more likely to convict than non-woman majority juries and are more likely to find a defendant guilty in a rape case.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = "Gender and Jury Deliberations: The Contributions of Social Science" by Lucy Fowler|issue = 1|pages = 1|url = http://scholarship.law.wm.edu/wmjowl/vol12/iss1/2|journal = William & Mary Journal of Race, Gender, and Social Justice|volume = 12|accessdate = 2015-12-15|date = October 2005|last1 = Fowler|first1 = Lucy}}</ref> Men are more likely to be influenced by the attractiveness of the defendant than women.<ref name=":0" />
There are significant differences in third-party punishment behavior between age groups. In a variation of the TP-DG, 8-year-olds based their punishment on the outcome of the unfair result and did not consider the intention of the actor in both second-party and third-party punishment decisions. Adolescents integrated the outcome and the intention when making second- but not third-party punishment decisions. Adults integrated the outcome and the intention of the act for both second- and third-party punishment. This demonstrates developmental differences in how third-party punishment decisions are made.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Outcomes and intentions in children's, adolescents', and adults' second- and third-party punishment behavior|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0010027714001115|journal = Cognition|date = 2014-10-01|pages = 97–103|volume = 133|issue = 1|doi = 10.1016/j.cognition.2014.06.001|first = Michaela|last = Gummerum|first2 = Maria T.|last2 = Chu|pmid=24997554}}</ref>
==Parochial altruism== [[Parochialism|Parochial]] altruism refers to altruism that is directed in a preferential manner towards members of one's own social group.<ref name=Rusch>{{cite journal|last=Rusch|first=Hannes|title=The evolutionary interplay of intergroup conflict and altruism in humans: a review of parochial altruism theory and prospects for its extension|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|year=2014|volume=281|issue=1794|pages=20141539|doi=10.1098/rspb.2014.1539|pmid=25253457|pmc=4211448}}</ref> In order to examine this effect, a study examined the outcomes of TP-DG experiments carried out in between two [[Papua New Guinea]] indigenous groups. The games had 4 conditions, which included: players A (dictator), B (recipient), and C (observer) all from the same group; only A and B from the same group; only A and C from the same group; only B and C from the same group.<ref name="Parochial" /> Current [[Social behavior|behavioral theories]] state that norms are emergent from interactions within groups,<ref name=Bornstein1>{{cite journal|last=Bornstein|first=Gary|title=Intergroup Conflict: Individual, Group, and Collective Interests|journal=Personality and Social Psychology Review|year=2003|volume=7|issue=2|pages=129–145|doi=10.1207/S15327957PSPR0702_129-145|pmid=12676644|citeseerx=10.1.1.487.5022}}</ref> and therefore, outsiders don’t obey the norm nor benefit from the altruistic behavior the norm enforces. This theory would therefore predict that no punishment will occur in any of the cases except for the ABC treatment condition. However, it was found that punishment was qualitatively similar in all 4 conditions, which suggests that [[Egalitarianism|egalitarian]] sharing norms exist within-groups and also between-groups.<ref name="Parochial" />
It was observed that, while all 4 conditions exhibited egalitarian sharing norms, punishments were much higher in the ABC and BC conditions. This suggests that victims are more protected if the third-party observer belongs to same group as them. It was also found that the dictators expected much harsher punishments if third-party observers belonged to the same group as the victim. It was also found that transfers were higher in groups with the same A and B members, and lower in groups with the same A and C members, suggesting that the dictators expected leniency from third-party observers of their own group.<ref name="Parochial" />
==See also== *[[Altruism]] *[[Norm (social)]] *[[Experimental Economics]] *[[Dual inheritance theory]] *[[Behavioral Economics]] *[[Game Theory]] *[[Neuroeconomics]] *[[Juries in the United States|Juries]]

Press|isbn=978-0674930469}} * {{cite journal |vauthors=Enge S, Mothes H, Fleischhauer M, Reif A, Strobel A |title=Genetic variation of dopamine and serotonin function modulates the feedback-related negativity during altruistic punishment |journal=Sci Rep |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=2996 |year=2017 |pmid=28592831 |pmc=5462809 |doi=10.1038/s41598-017-02594-3 |url=|bibcode=2017NatSR...7.2996E }}

{{refimprove|date=December 2008}} '''Tradability''' is the property of a [[Good (economics and accounting)|good]] or [[Service (economics)|service]] that can be sold in another location distant from where it was produced. A good that is not tradable is called '''non-tradable'''. Different goods have differing levels of tradability: the higher the cost of transportation and the shorter the shelf life, the less tradable a good is. Prepared food, for example, is not generally considered a tradable good; it will be sold in the city in which it is produced and does not directly compete with other cities' prepared foods. [[Haircut]]s and [[massage]]s are also non-tradable.<ref name="economist 9304272">{{cite news | url= http://www.economist.com/node/9304272?story_id=9304272 | title= Mandarin 2.0 | publisher= [[economist.com]] | date= Jun 7, 2007 | accessdate= 2012}}</ref>
== Price equalization == Perfectly tradable goods, like shares of stock, are subject to the [[law of one price]]: they should cost the same amount wherever they are bought. This law requires an [[efficient market]]. Any discrepancy that may exist in pricing perfectly tradable goods because of [[foreign exchange market]] movements, for instance, is called an [[arbitrage]] opportunity. Goods that cannot be costlessly traded are not subject to this law.
Less than perfectly tradable goods subject to distortions such as the [[Penn effect]], for example, a lowering of prices in less wealthy place. Perfectly non-tradable goods are not subject to any leveling of price, thus the disparity between similar parcels of [[real estate]] in different locations.
There should be no distortions in [[purchasing power parity]] for perfectly tradable goods. The differences between it and other methods are the result of non-tradable goods and the above-mentioned Penn effect.

The '''Uduk''' are a [[Nilo-Saharan]] group from eastern [[Sudan]]. They call themselves ''Kwanim Pa'' and are culturally and linguistically related to neighboring communities, such as the [[Gumuz people|Gumuz]] and the [[Kwama people|Kwama]] from the Sudan-Ethiopia borderland. Due to the recent war in southern Sudan they have been forced to emigrate to other countries, especially [[Ethiopia]]. Following the peace agreement in 2005, some Uduk have started to return home.

{{Infobox women |image = Phuan Girls.JPG |caption = Two young Lao women in traditional clothes. |gii = 0.483 (2012) |gii_rank = 100th |matdeath = 470 (2010) |womparl = 25.0% (2012) |femed = 22.9% (2010) |womlab = 76.5% (2011) | ggg = 0.6993 (2013) | ggg_rank = 60th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} '''Laotian women''' have long been active participants in [[Laos|their nation]]'s society, involved in politics, driving social transformation and development, becoming active in the world of business and serving as [[nurse]]s and food producers for [[Military of Laos|the military]]. Due to modernization and [[Rural society in Laos|rural uprooting]], Lao women have begun to embrace lifestyles that are foreign to traditional Laotian ideals.<ref name=Lonely/>
==Legal status== [[File:Woman in Laos 1.jpg|thumb|250 px|Khmu woman in village Ban Huay fay, region [[Luang Prabang]], Laos]] [[File:Three Lao girls reading.JPG|thumb|250 px|Lao girls reading]] Under the [[Constitution of Laos]], Lao women are legally equal to Lao men. They have the right to vote and to inherit property. In practice, the roles and status of women in Lao society often depend on ethnic affiliation.<ref name=Lonely/> In some cases, as in the status of [[Lao Loum]] women, the youngest daughter is often assigned the task of caring for elderly parents in return for inheritance benefits like land and business.<ref name=Lonely/>
After receiving her inheritance, the daughter does not obtain direct control over the land or business, as her husband possesses executive power over such matters.<ref name=Lonely/> Other women from different ethnic groups do not inherit anything.<ref name=Lonely/> In 1993, the government of Lao established a program of land surveying and titling which was nominally more beneficial to female landholders. National legislation declaring Lao men and women as "equally entitled to hold property" was also promulgated, including the Family Law proclaiming that "any property purchased during marriage is regarded as joint property", and that the "land owned by a woman prior to her marriage remains her individual property, as does any land she inherits from her parents”.<ref name=WB>[http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/TOPICS/EXTARD/EXTAGISOU/0,,contentMDK:20960914~menuPK:2758776~pagePK:64168445~piPK:64168309~theSitePK:2502781,00.html Module 10 - The Lao People’s Democratic Republic: Preserving Women’s Rights in Land Titling], worldbank.org</ref>
==Workforce== Many rural Lao women undertake a variety of semi-formal roles in their communities, including handicrafts, commerce, public health, and education, in addition to their traditional roles as homemakers and the caretakers of children. In the cities and at the government level, Lao women are underrepresented, particularly in high-level positions. In terms of wages, women typically receive lower salaries than men.<ref name=Lonely/>
==Religion== In connection with [[Lao Buddhism]] and traditional beliefs, many Lao women are taught that they can only attain [[nirvana]] after they have been [[reincarnation|reborn as men]].<ref name=Lonely>Burke, Andrew and Justine Vaisutis. [https://books.google.com/books?id=jm4GBvwaF50C&pg=PA52&lpg=PA52&dq=nirvana+for+women+in+Laos&source=bl&ots=GrVk5lanbQ&sig=36p3Kl980G9mBPt7UI_yq-z_lXU&hl=en&ei=Y1_DTbKQDYG6tgfu482MBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFsQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=nirvana%20for%20women%20in%20Laos&f=false Women in Laos], Laos, Lonely Planet, 2007, 372 pages</ref>
==Education and training== [[File:Silk dying.JPG|thumb|250px|Two Laotian women and their silk product.]] [[File:Primary Laos.jpg|250px|thumb|right|School girls in a small village school in a rural area in northern Laos]] Fewer Laotian girls enroll in schools than boys.<ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=x0n9XTlljesC&pg=PT114&dq=women+paid+less+than+men+%22+Laos%22&hl=en&ei=4pfcTZXJJ83irAe8zOzGDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=lao&f=false The world's women, 2000: trends and statistics]''. [[United Nations]]. 2001. P. 87</ref> After [[World War II]], many women, such as the silk weavers of the Bai Hai population, became increasingly engaged in unskilled manual labour. Despite being less literate and educated than men on average (63% of Lao females can read and write, compared to 83% of males),<ref>"[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/la.html CIA World Factbook 2011: Laos]" [[Central Intelligence Agency]]</ref> Lao women increasingly became the primary wage earners of their family units, especially in rural areas.
In recent decades, Lao women have furthermore benefited from [[microfinancing]] programs offered by organizations such as the Social Economic Developers Association (SEDA). In such programs, women receive training in establishing businesses, business management, procurement of materials, mass production, price negotiation for products, financial management, marketing strategies, writing skills, business planning, and decision-making. This is intended to assist women in becoming empowered and obtaining "financial stability".<ref name=Halligan>Halligan, Charlotte. [http://www.asianweek.com/2009/09/02/laos-forgotten-women/ Laos' Forgotten Women], September 2, 2009</ref>
Another organization involved in women's education is the Lao Disabled Women's Development Centre, an institution that trains [[disability|handicapped]] Lao women. The Lao Disabled Women's Development Centre was established by Chanhpheng Sivila, and functioned primarily as a series of workshops before expanding in 2002.<ref name=Kemp>Kemp, Melody. [http://www.ips.org/mdg3/rights-laos-how-women-cope-with-disability-part-1-5/ RIGHTS-LAOS: How Women Cope With Disability – Part 1], Social and Economic Developers Association in Laos, November 20, 2009</ref> Another similar group focusing on the rights, empowerment, and health of Lao women is the Committee for Women's Advancement of the province of [[Sayaboury]].<ref name=WP>[http://laospdrnews.wordpress.com/category/womens-rights/ Sayaboury to focus on improve the public health service for women], In Health, Women's Rights, Archive for the ‘Women’s Rights’ Category, April 20–21, 2011</ref>
==Politics== {{Women in society sidebar}} The women of Lao obtained the right to vote and to be elected in 1958.<ref name=OWP/> They remain underrepresented in government at both local and national levels.<ref name=Lonely/>
In recent decades women have made notable inroads into politics. In 1997, [[Onechanh Thammavong]] became one of the vice-presidents of the [[National Assembly of Laos]].<ref name=OWP>[http://www.onlinewomeninpolitics.org/laos/laomain.htm Female candidates for National Assembly election promoted], In Women's Rights, March 29–30, 2011</ref> In March 2011, the National Assembly provided a seminar for forty-seven female candidates in advance of the 7th Lao general elections in April 2011, in order to instil the “significant duties of the national legislature body” in the women.<ref name=OWP/>
==Marriage== In Lao society, women who divorce their husbands are traditionally stigmatised, often finding it difficult to find another spouse.<ref name=Lonely/>
==Prostitution and trafficking== As with many of the poorer states of [[South-East Asia]], [[Human trafficking in Laos|human trafficking]] and [[prostitution]] are serious issues for Lao women.<ref name=State>[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eap/135997.htm 2009 Human Rights Report: Laos]. U.S. Department of State. March 11, 2010. Retrieved December 5, 2012.</ref><ref name=State2>[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41648.htm Laos]. U.S. Department of State. February 28, 2005. Retrieved December 5, 2012.</ref>

[https://books.google.com/books?id=BgOP9jp9OI8C&pg=PA1&lpg=PA1&dq=women+in+laos+rights&source=bl&ots=4aOF6gALSa&sig=E_BZ52oNZ4B5zBp9fbGO53zcxCg&hl=en&ei=HFjBTeunK9G1tweZ9cjDBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CEsQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=women%20in%20laos%20rights&f=false Introduction:Women’s Changing Rights to House and Land in Vietnam, Laos, and China], Lynne Rienner Publishers, 1999, 305 pages, {{ISBN|978-1-55587-817-7}} *[http://www.fidh.org/A-UN-body-expresses-concern-regarding-women A UN body expresses concern regarding women rights in Laos], 15 February 2005

{{infobox ethnic group |group = Yalunka |image = Jalonke.jpg |caption = Portrait of a Yalunka (1861) |popplace = [[Guinea]], [[Sierra Leone]], [[Senegal]] and [[Mali]] |langs = [[Yalunka language|Yalunka]] |rels = [[Islam]] 99% |related = [[Susu people]] }} The '''Yalunka''', also spelled '''Jallonke''', '''Yalonga''', '''Djallonké''', '''Djallonka''' or '''Dialonké''', are a [[Mande people|Mande]] people who have lived in the [[Futa Jallon]] ({{lang-fr|Fouta Djallon|links=no}}), a mountainous region in [[Guinea]], [[West Africa]] since about the 11th century.<ref name="Appiah2010p490">{{cite book|author1=Anthony Appiah|author2=Henry Louis Gates|title=Encyclopedia of Africa |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A0XNvklcqbwC |year=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-533770-9|page=490}}</ref><ref name="Wheat2016xviii">{{cite book|author=David Wheat|title=Atlantic Africa and the Spanish Caribbean, 1570-1640|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Fq0CAAAQBAJ |year=2016|publisher=University of North Carolina Press|isbn=978-1-4696-2380-1|pages=xviii, 48}}</ref> The name Yalunka literally means "inhabitants of the Jallon (mountains)."
They are a branch of the [[Mandé peoples]] of [[West Africa]], and closely related to the [[Susu people]].<ref>{{cite book|author=David Wheat| title=Atlantic Africa and the Spanish Caribbean, 1570-1640| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Fq0CAAAQBAJ |year=2016| publisher=University of North Carolina Press| isbn=978-1-4696-2380-1| pages=51–52}}</ref> Some scholars classify the two as one group. The Yalunka are notable for having first converted to Islam, but then renouncing Islam en masse when Muslim [[Fula people]] began dominating their region.<ref name="Shillington2013p537"/> The Yalunka fought against the [[Fula jihads]], left Futa Jallon, migrated and established new towns such as [[Falaba]] near the region where [[Rokel River]] starts, while others settled among the [[Koranko]], [[Limba people (Sierra Leone)|Limba]] and [[Kissi people]]. Ultimately, the Yalunka were subdued and absorbed by the [[Fulani Empire]].<ref name="Shillington2013p537">{{cite book|author=Kevin Shillington|title=Encyclopedia of African History 3-Volume Set|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=umyHqvAErOAC&pg=PA537 |year=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-45670-2|page=537}}</ref>
They speak the [[Yalunka language]] which belongs to the Mande branch of the [[Niger–Congo language family]]. Yalunka is mutually intelligible with [[Susu language|Susu]], another Mande language. In the contemporary era, the Yalunka are concentrated mostly in Guinea and [[Sierra Leone]].
==History== The ancient history of Yalunka people is unknown. The earliest evidence suggests that sometime around the eleventh century, the Yalunka people arrived in the hilly plateau region of the Futa Jallon in Guinea.<ref name="Appiah2010p490"/> They converted to Islam. After the seventeenth century, Islamic theocracies supported by the [[Fula people]] began a period of Fula dominance and their version of Islam in the region traditionally occupied by the Yalunka. The Yalunka people, along with the [[Susu people]], then renounced Islam.<ref name="Shillington2013p537"/> The Fula people and their leaders such as Ibrahima Musa and Ibrahima Sori launched a series of jihads targeted against the Yalunka in the eighteenth century. The Yalunka were defeated, subdued and returned to Islam in 1778.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Mark R. Lipschutz|author2=R. Kent Rasmussen|title=Dictionary of African Historical Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QYoPkk04Yp4C |year=1989|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-06611-3|pages=88, 113, 236}}</ref>
==Religion and traditional beliefs== The Yalunka are predominantly [[Muslim]] (99%). At the same time, they have retained many pre-Islamic beliefs and practices, combining the two in a syncretic way. One of their traditional practice is ''Barinkiina'', which involves making sacrifices in memory of their ancestors to gain power. They also make sacrifices for ''Suxurena'' and ''Nyinanna'', or nature spirits, in order to gain powers.<ref name="Taylor2014p153">{{cite book|author=Bankole Kamara Taylor|title=Sierra Leone: The Land, Its People and History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I__jAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA153 |year=2014|publisher=New Africa Pres|isbn=978-9987-16-038-9|page=153}}</ref> However, they are devoted Muslims and their fear of persecution have prevented them from converting to other religions.<ref name="Taylor2014p153"/>
The New Testament was translated into the [[Yalunka language]] by [[Pioneer Bible Translators]]'s current president, Greg Pruett in 2013.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}
==Society== The Yalunka live in larger settlements established since the 18th century. The Yalunka region is mixed savannah and forest. The country is hilly, and most of it is 1,000 to 2,000 feet above sea level. Most Yalunka settlements are located in the valleys between the hills. Since the 1950s, many Yalunka have migrated to cities to find work.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}
The Yalunka people commonly practice [[polygyny]] (having multiple wives). Arranged marriages are their traditional practice, and they follow the [[Sharia|Islamic law]] that a man may have up to four living wives. The first wife has seniority and authority over wives he marries later.<ref name="Taylor2014p153"/> The husband, according to Bankole Taylor, "has complete control over his wives and is responsible for feeding and clothing them".<ref name="Taylor2014p153"/>
The Yalunka society is [[patriarchal]], consisting of households headed by a man, his wife or wives, and their unmarried children.<ref name="Taylor2014p153"/> Extended households form a compound, which may consist of two or more married men from the same father and their families, each living in a separate hut.<ref name="Taylor2014p153"/>
==Economy== {{refimprove section|date=November 2016}} The Yalunka are primarily subsistence [[farmers]], with rice and millet being their staple crops. Peanuts, sweet potatoes, maize, and beans are also grown. Chickens, herds of cattle, and flocks of sheep and goats are kept. Goats and cattle provide milk as a food source, which is used directly and processed for cheese and other products. This livestock, such as goats and cattle, are very important as a marker of wealth and because they serve as bride-price payments. The boy's family gives animals to the girl's family before the marriage takes place. These animals are also used as a means of economic exchange.
Among the Yalunka, herding is done by the children. The women milk the cattle, churn the butter, and help the men in some of the agricultural work. Honey is another important commodity among the Yalunka. The people suspend large, water-tight baskets in trees. The bees use the baskets as hives and make honey in them. Every year, between four and six gallons of honey may be gathered from each basket.
==Notable Yalunka== *[[Manga Sewa]], was a great Yalunka chief in Northern Sierra Leone.
